DOC.HEAD: Federal Agencies Probe Air Crash That Claimed 6 Lives
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators Wednesday began examining the wreckage of a commuter plane for the cause of a crash that killed all six people aboard. The twin-engine United Express turboprop went down in a field and burst into flames just short of the runway late Tuesday while en route from Seattle to Pasco via Yakima. At a news conference, United Express president Craig Belmondo raised the possibility that wing icing contributed to the crash but said it was ``much too early to speculate'' on the cause. Fire officials found ice at the crash scene but Belmondo said it had not been determined whether the ice came from the British Aerospace Jetstream 31, a 19-passenger plane. The crew contacted the airline's dispatch center at the Tri City Airport here within three to five miles of landing, as is routine, and gave no indication of a problem, Belmondo said. He did not know if there was any communication between the plane and the airport tower after that. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Dave Duff said the plane hit 100 feet short of the runway; Belmondo said it went in 500 to 700 feet short. Investigators from the National Transportation safety Board and the FAA arrived Wednesday. United Express has deicing equipment at Yakima but it was not immediately known if it was used on the plane before its departure for Pasco, a flight of about 80 miles which usually takes about 30 minutes. Visibility at the time of the crash was seven miles and wind was calm, Duff said. The plane was not equipped with voice and flight data recorders that larger commercial airlines are required to carry. The plane was built in Scotland in 1987 and delivered to United Express in December of that year, Belmondo said. It had 5,000 hours of flight time and had its last maintenance inspection on Dec. 20, he said. The aircraft had no record of any major mechanical problems, he said. The pilot, Capt. Barry Roberts, 38, had more than 11 years of regional flying experience with more than 6,600 hours of total flying time, including more than 660 hours in British Aerospace Jetstream aircraft, Belmondo said. Co-pilot Doug McInroe, 25, joined United Express in August with more than two years flying experience, Belmondo said. He said he did not know who was piloting the plane when it crashed. United Express, based at Pasco, serves 15 cities in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Montana. It began commercial service in 1987.
